summary: This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Christopher Dilorio to the SEC and other officials, alleging widespread financial crimes, money laundering, and corrupt connections between Apollo Global Management, Jeffrey Epstein, Jared Kushner, and various shell companies. It accuses the SEC of corruption and obstruction for failing to investigate these claims.

persons.name: Christopher Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, making detailed allegations of financial crimes, money laundering, and SEC corruption involving Apollo, Epstein, Kushner, and others.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Mentioned in a forwarded press release as the Attorney for the United States charging bank CEO Stephen Calk.

persons.name: Stephen M. Calk
persons.context: Charged with corruptly soliciting a presidential administration position in exchange for approving loans.

persons.name: Phillip Frost
persons.context: Accused by the SEC of making $27 million in pump-and-dump stock schemes; linked to money laundering allegations.

persons.name: Leon Black
persons.context: Allegedly connected to Jeffrey Epstein, Jared Kushner, and Russian interests; accused of involvement in money laundering through shells.

persons.name: Jared Kushner
persons.role: Senior White House aide, son-in-law of President Trump
persons.context: Allegedly connected to Apollo/Epstein financing deals, including the 666 Fifth Avenue deal brokered by Apollo.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Allegedly running an extortion/Ponzi/slush fund and connected to Leon Black/Apollo and money laundering shells like Environmental Solutions Worldwide.

persons.name: Joshua Harris
persons.context: Mentioned as a Milken protégé and Apollo founding partner; considered for a White House job after Apollo gave Kushner a loan.

persons.name: Marc Rowan
persons.context: Mentioned in connection with Apollo's dealings and the 666 Fifth Avenue financing.

persons.name: George Economou
persons.context: Allegedly involved in money laundering through DryShips and connected to Marc Bistricer and Andrew Ekonomou.

persons.name: Marc Bistricer
persons.context: Led investment house Kalani, which lent to George Economou's DryShips; linked to Toronto-based financial networks.

persons.name: Andrew Ekonomou
persons.context: Obscure medieval historian turned lawyer helping lead Trump's legal team in the Russia investigation; linked to Atlanta-based H&L Equities.

persons.name: Stephen Feinberg
persons.context: Chosen by Trump to lead intelligence advisory panel; linked to money laundering banks like Bawag/Refco and HSH.

persons.name: Stephanie Avakian
persons.role: Co-Director of SEC Division of Enforcement
persons.context: Mentioned in context of alleged 'home cooking' where SEC dropped Apollo investigation after Kushner met with Apollo's Harris.

persons.name: Howard E. Heiss
persons.context: Attorney with focus on government regulatory investigations; mentioned in connection with Apollo/Kushner dealings.

persons.name: Jamie Gorelick
persons.context: Washington litigator represented in corporate matters; firm linked to former FBI Director Robert Mueller.

persons.name: Robert Mueller
persons.context: Joined WilmerHale after serving as FBI Director; mentioned in the context of legal networks.

persons.name: Eliot Spitzer
persons.role: Former New York State Attorney General
persons.context: Announced indictment in $50 million boiler room stock fraud scheme; later taken down by a Russian hooker according to the email.

persons.name: Loretta Lynch
persons.role: Former U.S. Attorney for the Eastern District of New York
persons.context: Announced indictment in $50 million boiler room stock fraud scheme with Eliot Spitzer.

persons.name: Carl Kline
persons.context: White House whistleblower who spoke out on security clearance controversy involving Kushner.

connections.description: Alleged financial and social connections; Epstein's Financial Trust Company filed in Leon Black/Apollo's Environmental Solutions Worldwide shell.
Apollo provided financing for Kushner's 666 Fifth Avenue deal; Kushner met with Apollo's Joshua Harris at the White House.
Apollo gave Kushner's company a $180 million loan; SEC dropped probe into Apollo a month later.
Bistricer's investment house Kalani lent to Economou's DryShips, alleged to be a money laundering shell.
Linked through alleged money laundering networks involving banks like Bawag/Refco and HSH.
Co-founders of Apollo Global Management, both Milken protégés.
Linked through SEC charges and alleged money laundering schemes via shell companies.
Email claims Spitzer was 'taken down by a Russian hooker'.

events.title: Email Alleging Apollo/Epstein/Kushner Connections
events.description: Christopher Dilorio sends detailed emails to SEC and officials alleging financial crimes, money laundering, and corrupt ties between Apollo, Epstein, Kushner, and shell companies.

events.title: SEC Approves Another Fraud
events.description: Dilorio claims the SEC approved another massive fraud on the investing public involving a money laundering shell linked to Greek shipping and George Economou.

events.title: SEC Drops Apollo Investigation
events.description: SEC dropped investigation into Apollo Global Management a month after the firm gave Jared Kushner's company a $180 million loan.

events.title: Apollo Receives $60+ Billion Inflows
events.description: Apollo Global Management reported over $60 billion in inflows in 2018, following its dealings with Kushner and dropped SEC probe.

events.title: Apollo-Citigroup Loan to Kushner
events.description: Apollo and Citigroup loaned Kushner companies millions, as reported by the New York Times.

events.title: Whistleblower Intimidation Attempt
events.description: Dilorio reports an anonymous, threatening phone call attempting to intimidate him as a whistleblower, which he considers a felony.

keyFacts: The whistleblower alleges the SEC is a 'grossly corrupt criminal organization' that intentionally ignores money laundering and fraud in shell companies.
Jeffrey Epstein's only SEC filing was in Leon Black/Apollo's shell company Environmental Solutions Worldwide, suggesting a financial link.
The SEC dropped an investigation into Apollo Global Management a month after Apollo gave Jared Kushner's family business a $180 million loan.
Apollo Global Management received over $60 billion in inflows in 2018, following its financial dealings with Kushner and the dropped SEC probe.
The email chain links multiple figures (Leon Black, George Economou, Stephen Feinberg) to alleged money laundering networks involving shell companies and Russian connections.
